title: Between 1 April 2019 and 31 March 2020, will an armed group from Mali engage in a campaign that systematically kills 1,000 or more civilians in Mali?
preds: I start from the current forecast of 5% as a baseline. Although I think the current forecast takes into account the attack by suspected dozo militias on a Fulani village that killed around 160 people in March, it doesn't account for the recent spike in attacks by suspected Fulani herdsmen against dozo communities. As a result, I will raise the forecast by 2.5%. I raise the forecast by further 2.5% due to the spreading the influence of Islamist militias, which have links to the Fulani militias and have the capacity to inflict heavy casualties on Dozo civilians.

Anyone trying to forecast this question faces a number of challenges. The first is that there are numerous Armed Groups operating in the region, sometimes with different and sometimes with shared goals and territories. Further, the lines between “jihadist” and “non-jihadist” armed groups are very blur. Fighters often pass back and forth between all types of groups, based on their convenience. The cooperation between non-jihadist and jihadist armed groups is rife. This fluidity has led to frequent allegations that both pro-government and formerly separatist or non-jihadist armed groups have collaborated with various jihadist groups. Given the ongoing shifts of the security and political situation in the region, any attempt to map this multitude of groups is by its nature inexact. However, it is less likely that 1 k can be attributed to a specific Armed Group.

There is a 45% chance of a systematic killing campaign to occur due to recent violence by Jihadist groups within Mali. In march, gunmen killed around 110 people in one of the most deadly attacks on civilians within central Mali in a long while. Growing presence of Jihadist and extremist groups is to blame for the recent killings, which are likely to grow into more killings. Growing tensions between Islamic State and Al-Qaeda forces in the region will lead to civilians getting mixed up in the conflict and killings of civilians as ways to retaliate. These groups are also taking advantage of ethnic tensions between groups, where ethnic conflicts tend to lead to a large number of deaths. 
https://www.nytimes.com/2019/03/23/world/africa/mali-dozens-killed.html

This is an update after educating myself a little more about recent conflict in Mali. My original estimate was 5%; however, there is frequent violence in Mali with fatalities at the hands of armed groups. I may raise this closer to 100% near the closing period, depending on progress of ongoing conflict by that time.

I can believe there will be violence that kills civilians, likely several times. But 1000 or more civilian deaths is exceedingly rare. I can easily imagine some form of genocide evolving here (or somewhere else similarly unstable), sometime within the coming years or decades, but I think the conditional probability of such occurring within the next 12 months here is very low. I would like to caveat this estimate by saying that, to my knowledge, genocide (or other deliberate mass killing) is only ever "predictable" after the fact with the benefit of hindsight. Hitler's "final solution," the Khmer Rouge killing fields and Rwandan bloodshed (as 20th century examples) were not seen coming in advance, and I think significant (further) violence against civilians in Mali of such a scale is well imaginable but not predictable.

It seems that there is a dangerous combination here: historical conflict among three ethnics groups (Bambara, Peuhl or Fulani (Muslim) and Dogon (traditional African religions)) for land and water, Islamist armed group moving South and recruiting from the Peuhl, the Dogon putting more pressure for water due to climate change. The strikes and retaliation seems to be already in place, being the spark for the systematic killing of civilians. [1] There are armed groups from Dogon and Bambara (the Dan Na Ambassagou and Dozo groups, in addition to the Jihadi groups) so the means for such attacks already exist. [2] Mitigating factors: French and UN peacekeeping forces (MINUSMA). Aggravating factors: Mali's government inability to investigate, respond and protect civilians, "likely because it relies on the self-defense groups to provide security in areas which there is no law enforcement." [2] The UN Security Council is meeting to discuss the deteriorating situation in Mali [3], "As fighting intensifies, some countries are pulling their soldiers out of the peacekeeping force." Mali warns that any cuts in UN forces will strengthen militants.
